description: From Middle English frisk (â€œlively, friskyâ€), from Old French frisque (â€œlively, jolly, blithe, fine, spruce, gayâ€), of Germanic origin, perhaps from Middle Dutch frisc (â€œfreshâ€) or Old High German frisc (â€œfreshâ€), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *friskaz (â€œfreshâ€). Cognate with Icelandic frÃ­skur (â€œfrisky, freshâ€). More at fresh.

Alternative etymology derives frisk from an alteration (due to Old French fresche (â€œfreshâ€)) of Old French fricque, frique (â€œsmart, strong, playful, brightâ€), from Gothic *ğ†ğ‚ğŒ¹ğŒºğƒ (*friks, â€œgreedy, hungryâ€), from Proto-Germanic *frekaz, *frakaz (â€œgreedy, activeâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *preg- (â€œgreedy, fierceâ€). Cognate with Middle Dutch vrec (â€œgreedy, avariciousâ€), German frech (â€œinsolentâ€), Old English frec (â€œgreedy, eager, bold, daring, dangerousâ€). More at freak.

entries.meaning: A little playful skip or leap; a brisk and lively movement.
The act of frisking, of searching for something by feeling someone's body.
examples: The customs officer gave me a frisk after I went through the metal detector.

verbs.description: frisk (third-person singular simple present frisks, present participle frisking, simple past and past participle frisked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To frolic, gambol, skip, dance, leap.
(transitive) To search (someone) by feeling their body and clothing.
examples: The police frisked the suspiciously-acting individual and found a knife as well as a bag of marijuana.
